title: Using Beam Shaders with CLI wallet
description: This document describes how to use Beam Shaders with CLI wallet running on a local network

children.value: Using Beam Shaders with CLI wallet

{% hint style="danger" %}
This page is somewhat obsolete, and is replaced with
Shaders are applied after the third fork with height 1500. Therefore, for faster testing, we recommend to define lower heights using the
Create at least one Beam node[link] with
CLI wallet connected to your Beam node
or to one of the Beam bootstrap nodes.
You must have funds in your wallet to pay the fee.
There are two types of Shaders in Beam:
- implements Smart Contract functionality, is stored on the blockchain and are running on Beam nodes.
- implements Smart Contract API and is running in Beam wallet.
All examples refer to a sample application 'mydapp' which has two
Shaders: App Shader(app.wasm) and Contract Shader(contract.wasm).
First of all, you need to know the available actions of a contract. To see all commands supported by the App Shader enter the following command:
The output is a json format line:
For convenience, let's put it this way:
As you can see above, there are two roles in this example:
. Each role has its own actions with or without required attributes. In this example, role
), is the frequently required attribute. We get it after our contract has been deployed. The same contract which has been deployed with different attributes, will have different values.
There are required flags that need to be passed to work with the contract:
All arguments are passed separated by commas. For example:
If the action has additional attributes, they also are separated by commas:
To work with the contract, it needs to be deployed. In our Vault example contract, the deployment corresponds to the
action. Based on our knowledge, we got the following command to
